title: Could Microsoft Let OpenAI Go Free?
description: In this episode, we dive into the evolving relationship between Microsoft and OpenAI, and explore what could happen if OpenAI were to gain more freedom from its exclusive partnership with Microsoft Azure.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Hello and welcome to another episode of 'Life is Artificial', where we explore the cutting edge of technology, innovation, and what the future could look like.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Today, we're talking about a fascinating story involving two tech giants: Microsoft and OpenAI. Now, if you've been following the rise of artificial intelligence, these two names should be quite familiar. Microsoft has been the major financial backer and cloud partner of OpenAI since 2019, and together they've managed to push the boundaries of what generative AI can do. But there's an interesting twist coming up, one that might surprise you—what if Microsoft decided to let OpenAI go free?

script.speaker: Host
script.text: The source for today's discussion comes from a recent article by The Economist titled 'What if Microsoft let OpenAI go free?' You can find the full article using the link in the show notes. It's a thought-provoking piece, and it paints a picture of a partnership that has been both wildly successful and a little bit restrictive. So let's unpack that.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: First, let's look at why this partnership has worked so well so far. Since 2019, Microsoft has provided over $13 billion in cash and cloud computing resources to OpenAI, which at the time was just a startup with big ambitions. In exchange, Microsoft gained the exclusive right to run OpenAI's models on its cloud platform, Azure. This deal has helped both companies immensely—Microsoft got to integrate cutting-edge AI into its software products, and OpenAI got the financial support it needed to push its technology to new heights.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: In fact, this partnership has helped Azure close the gap with Amazon Web Services, or AWS. Analysts estimate that Azure's revenue grew by around 30% year-on-year recently, while AWS grew at about 19%. This means that the Microsoft-OpenAI partnership has had some real commercial impact, not just in the AI world but also in the broader cloud computing market.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: But as The Economist article points out, not everything is rosy. Just like Michelangelo and the Medicis back in the Renaissance, sometimes OpenAI seems to feel a bit constrained by its wealthy benefactor. Some board members and investors are reportedly interested in loosening Microsoft’s grip. They want OpenAI to be able to expand to other cloud providers like AWS, which still holds about half of the cloud computing market. This would certainly boost OpenAI’s influence and allow its technology to reach an even wider audience.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: There's also the question of antitrust concerns. Regulatory authorities in the United States and the United Kingdom have started looking into the relationship between Microsoft and OpenAI. The issue here is that exclusive deals of this nature can sometimes raise red flags for competition authorities. The argument for more openness is not just about helping OpenAI grow but also about avoiding potential regulatory roadblocks down the line.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: And here's where things get even more interesting. Microsoft itself may not be as opposed to giving OpenAI more freedom as you might think. The article mentions that Microsoft has already started reducing its dependence on OpenAI. Last year, when Sam Altman, OpenAI's CEO, was briefly ousted and then reinstated, it reportedly shook Microsoft’s CEO, Satya Nadella. Since then, Microsoft has diversified by adding models from other AI companies like Mistral, and by hiring many of the staff from Inflection, a competitor of OpenAI.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: There’s also a clause, according to The Economist, that could allow OpenAI to dissolve its ties with Microsoft if its models reach a level called artificial general intelligence, or AGI. AGI is often thought of as the holy grail of AI—a point where an AI system possesses the ability to understand, learn, and apply knowledge across a wide range of tasks, similar to a human. Some enthusiasts believe we could be just a few years away from this milestone, though it's still highly subjective and debated.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: AWS, for its part, would love to work with OpenAI. Matt Garman, AWS’s new head, expressed interest in getting OpenAI’s models onto their platform. Amazon's cloud business might still be the biggest, but when it comes to generative AI, it's clear that AWS is playing catch-up with Azure and Google Cloud. Adding OpenAI’s models could help AWS compete in this crucial area.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: But here's the catch—The Economist points out that the trend in the cloud industry has been moving away from exclusivity for some time. Companies are increasingly opting for multi-cloud strategies, where they use services from different cloud providers to get the best out of each one. So, if OpenAI were to work with AWS, it wouldn't necessarily mean breaking its relationship with Azure—it could just mean expanding.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Ultimately, whether or not Microsoft lets OpenAI 'go free' is about finding the right balance. The partnership has propelled both companies to new heights, but it’s clear there are benefits to more flexibility and openness, not just for OpenAI, but for the broader AI and cloud industry as well. Microsoft could still benefit from its equity stake in OpenAI, even if OpenAI partnered with AWS or other cloud providers. And let’s not forget, antitrust concerns might also push for a change sooner rather than later.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So what do you think? Should Microsoft loosen its hold and let OpenAI go free, or should it continue to maintain this exclusive relationship? As always, I’d love to hear your thoughts. Reach out on social media or leave a comment, and let’s continue this conversation.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: That's all for today’s episode of 'Life is Artificial'. Remember to check out the link to the full article from The Economist in the show notes if you want a deeper dive into this story. Thanks for tuning in, and until next time, stay curious.
